channel.title: Mr. Eric

item.title: Ways To Express Yourself (G4)
item.description: There are MANY ways to express ourselves. You must know one, that is, chatting. You use words to express your self while chatting. But what if you can’t express yourself through words? There are also many ways to express yourself. In this text I’ll tell you about two ways: Drama, and Music. And it’s all my opinion.

item.title: Volunteer or not (G4)
item.description: Have you ever volunteered before? If you haven’t, then you should try your best to volunteer more. However, you don’t need to volunteer because everyone has their civil rights, which don’t force you to volunteer. Therefore you could not do it if you can’t, or don’t want to do it!

item.title: Should We Reach Out (G4)
item.description: Had you ever met a homeless person? Did you decide to help them of not? However, it’s important to help them anyway you could, normal people should, and could help the homeless. but if he don’t needs help, you could leave him alone for some time. There might be someone which could help him! Here’s a story:

item.title: Euclid Book II PROP. X. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If a line (AB) be bisected (at C) and divided externally (at D), the sum of the squares on the segments (AD, DB) made by the external point is equal to twice the square on half the line, and twice the square on the segment between the points of section.

item.title: Euclid Book II PROP. IX. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If a line (AB) be bisected (at C) and divided into two unequal parts (at D), the sum of the squares on the unequal parts (AD, DB) is double the sum of the squares on half the line (AC), and on the segment (CD) between the points of section.

item.title: Euclid Book II PROP. VIII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If a line (AB) be divided into two parts (at C), the square on the sum the whole line (AB) and either segment (BC) is equal to four times the rectangle contained by the whole line (AB) and that segment, together with the square on the other segment (AC).

item.title: Euclid Book II PROP. VII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If a right line (AB) be divided into any two parts (at C), the sum of the squares on the whole line (AB) and either segment (CB) is equal to twice the rectangle (2AB.CB) contained by the whole line and that segment, together with the square on the other segment.

item.title: Euclid Book II PROP. VI. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If a line (AB) be bisected (at C), and divided externally in any point (D), the rectangle (AD.BD) contained by the segments made by the external point, together with the square on half the line, is equal to the square on the segment between the middle point and the point of external division.

item.title: Euclid Book II PROP. V. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If a line (AB) be divided into two equal parts (at C), and also into two unequal parts (at D), the rectangle (AD.DB) contained by the unequal parts, together with the square on the part (CD) between the points of section, is equal to the square on half the line.

item.title: Euclid Book II PROP. IV. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If a line (AB) be divided into any two parts (at C), the square on the whole line is equal to the sum of the squares on the parts (AC, CB), together with twice their rectangle.

item.title: Euclid Book II PROP. III. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If a line (AB) be divided into two segments (at C), the rectangle contained by the whole line and either segment (CB) is equal to the square on that segment together with the rectangle contained by the segments.

item.title: Euclid Book II PROP. II. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If a line (AB) be divided into any two parts (at C), the square on the whole line is equal to the sum of the rectangles contained by the whole and each of the segments (AC, CB).

item.title: Euclid Book II PROP. I. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If there be two lines (A, BC), one of which is divided into any number of parts (BD, DE, EC), the rectangle contained by the two lines (A, BC), is equal to the sum of the rectangles contained by the undivided line (A) and the several parts of the divided line.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XLVIII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If the square on one side (AB) of a triangle be equal to the sum of the squares on the remaining sides (AC, CB), the angle (C) opposite to that side is a right angle.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XLVII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: In a right-angled triangle (ABC) the square on the hypotenuse (AB) is equal to the sum of the squares on the other two sides (AC, BC).

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XLVI. -- PROBLEM.
item.description: On a given right line (AB) to describe a square.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XLV. -- PROBLEM.
item.description: To construct a parallelogram equal to a given rectilineal figure (ABCD), and having an angle equal to a given rectilineal angle (X).

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XLIV. -- PROBLEM.
item.description: To a given, right line (AB) to apply a parallelogram which shall be equal to a given triangle (C), and have one of its angles equal to a given angle (D).

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XLIII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: In any parallelogram the complements of the parallelograms about the diameter equal one another.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XLII. -- PROBLEM.
item.description: To construct a parallelogram equal to a given triangle (ABC), and having an angle equal to a given angle (D).

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XLI. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If a parallelogram (ABCD) and a triangle (EBC) be on the same base (BC) and between the same parallels, the parallelogram is double of the triangle.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XL. -- THEOREM.
item.description: Equal triangles (ABC, DEF) on equal bases (BC, EF) which form parts of the same right line, and on the same side of the line, are between the same parallels.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXIX. -- THEOREM.
item.description: Equal triangles (BAC, BDC) on the same base (BC) and on the same side of it are between the same parallels.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXVIII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: Two triangles on the equal bases and between the same parallels are equal.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXVII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: Triangles (ABC, DBC) on the same base (BC) and between the same parallels (AD, BC) are equal.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXVI. -- THEOREM.
item.description: Parallelograms (BD, FH) on equal bases (BC, FG) and between then same parallels are equal.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXV. -- THEOREM.
item.description: Parallelograms on the same base (BC) and between the same parallels are equal.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXIV. -- THEOREM.
item.description: The opposite sides (AB, CD,; AC, BD) and the opposite angles (A, D; B, C) of a parallelogram are equal to one another, and either diagonal bisects the parallelogram.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXIII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: The right lines (AC, BD) which join the adjacent extremities of two equal and parallel right lines (AB, CD) are equal and parallel.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If any side (AB) of a triangle (ABC) be produced (to D), the external angle (CBD) is equal to the sum of the two internal non-adjacent angles (A, C), and the sum of the three internal angles is equal to two right angles.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXI. -- PROBLEM.
item.description: Through a given point (C) to draw a right line parallel to a given right line.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXX. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If two right lines (AB, CD) be parallel to the same right line (EF), they are parallel to one another.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXIX. -- THEOREM.
item.description:
If a right line (EF) intersect two parallel right lines (AB, CD), it makes:

  1. the alternate angles (AGH, GHD) equal to one another;
  2. the exterior angle (EGB) equal to the corresponding interior angle (GHD);
  3. the two interior angles (BGH, GHD) on the same side equal to two right angles.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXVIII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If a right line (EF) intersect two parallel right lines (AB, CD) makes the exterior angle (EGB) equal to its corresponding interior angle (GHD), or makes two interior angles (BGH, GHD) on the same side equal to two right angles, the two right lines are parallel.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXVII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If a right line (EF) intersecting two right lines (AB, CD) makes the alternate angles (AEF, EFD) equal to each other, these lines are parallel.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXVI. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If two triangles (ABC, DEF) have two angles B, C) of one equal respectively to two angles (E, F) of the other, and a side of one equal to a side similarly placed with respect to the equal angles of the other, the triangles are equal in every respect.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXV. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If two triangles (ABC, DEF) have two sides (AB, AC) of one respectively equal to two sides (DE, DF) of the other, but the base (BC) of one greater than the base (EF) of the other, the angle (A) contained by the sides of that which has the greater base is greater them the angle (D) contained by the sides of the other.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXIV. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If two triangles (ABC, DEF) have two sides (AB, AC) of one respectively equal to two sides (DE, DF) of the other, but the contained angle (BAC) of one greater than the contained angle (EDF) of the other, the base of that which has the greater angle is greater than the base of the other.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXIII. -- PROBLEM.
item.description: At a given point (A) in a given right line (AB) to make an angle equal to a given rectilineal angle (DEF)

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXII. -- PROBLEM.
item.description: To construct a triangle which three sides shall be respectively equal to three given lines (A, B, C), the sum of every two of which is greater than the third.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXI. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If two lines (BD, CD) be drawn to a point (D) within a triangle from the extremities of its base (BD), their sum is less than the sum of the remaining sides (BA, CA), but they contain a greater angle.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XX. -- THEOREM.
item.description: The sum of any two sides (BA, AC) of a triangle (ABC) is greater than the third.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XIX. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If one angle (B) of a triangle (ABC) be greater than another angle (C), the side (AC) which it opposite to the greater angle is greater than the side (AB) which is opposite to the less.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XVIII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If in any triangle (ABC) one side (AC) be greater than another (AB), the angle opposite to the greater side is greater than the angle opposite to the less.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XVII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: Any two angles (B, C) of a triangle (ABC) are together less than two right angles.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XVI. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If any side (BC) of a triangle (ABC) be produced, the exterior angle (ACD) is greater than either of the interior non-adjacent angles.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XV. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If Two right lines (AB, CD) intersect one another, the opposite angles are equal (CEA=DEB, and BEC=AED)

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XIV. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If at a point (B) in a right line (BA) two other right lines (CB, BD) on opposite sides make the adjacent angles (CBA, ABD) together equal to two right angles, these two right lines form one continuous line.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XIII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: The adjacent angles (ABC, ABD) which one right lines (AB) standing on another (CD) makes with it are either both right angles, or their sum is equal to two right angles.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XII. -- PROBLEM.
item.description: To draw a perpendicular to a given indefinite right line (AB) from a given point (C) without it.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XI. -- PROBLEM.
item.description: From a given point (C) in a given right line (AB) to draw a right line perpendicular to the given line.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. X. -- PROBLEM.
item.description: To bisect a given finite right line (AB).

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. IX. -- PROBLEM.
item.description: To bisect a given rectilineal angle (BAC).

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. VIII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If two triangles (ABC, DEF) have two sides (AB, AC) of one respectively equal to two sides…

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. VII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If two triangles (ACB, ADB) on the same base (AB) and on the same side of it have one …

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. VI. – THEOREM.
item.description: If two angles (B, C) of a triangle be equal, the sides (AC, AB) opposite to them are also equal.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. V. – THEOREM.
item.description: The angles (ABC, ACB) at the base (BC) of an isosceles triangle are equal to one another…

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. IV. – THEOREM.
item.description: If two triangle (BAC, EDF) have two sides (BA, AC) of one equal respectively to two sides…

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. III. – PROBLEM.
item.description: From the greater (AB) of two given right lines to cut off a part equal to (C) the less.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. II. – PROBLEM.
item.description: From a given point (A) to draw a right line equal to a given finite right line (BC).

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. I. – PROBLEM.
item.description: On a given finite right line (AB) to construct an equilateral triangl.
